ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write a scientific grant proposal.
I performed clinical research in my lab and learned about laboratory techniques and proper literature review.
I learned a lot about performing research and troubleshooting.

- experience in working in a basic neuroscience lab
- practice in the process of grant writing for the end-of-semester fall proposal
how to write research proposal
Independent research at my lab, studying CCEPs in brain
I learned a lot about the way that stress neurotransmitters interact in the human and primate brains as well as a lot about the different research techniques used to investigate different systems.

I continued to cultivate skills in biochemical research, scientific writing, data analysis, and project management. My particular protocol involved Western blotting, SDS-PAGE, molecular cloning, plasmid purification, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Nothing in particular.
This is an independent research course, so I don't think much should be changed. It works well.

I think it is well organized to allow students to do a 2-semester neuroscience thesis. Experiences really depend on labs/PI's, so my lab was good about this, but the course could emphasize some more flexibility with the 10 hour/week requirement (allowing remote hours while doing writing assignments for the class, allowing students to do more some weeks and less others, etc)

Also I wonder if the 10 page grant proposal could have been 7 or 8 pages, since I felt that my writing was not longer concise given the current length of the assignment
it was well organized.

Strengths - being able to complete work on my own time 
Weakness - none

I learned a lot once I was able to find a good mentor but before then, there was no instruction and no support from the neuroscience DUS's. I felt very lost and had a hard time knowing what to do in the beginning. There needs to at least be better instruction with how to get started.
This course ran smoothly. The requirements for the research summary and fall grant proposal were outlined well, and we were given sufficient time to complete out work.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are a B.S. Neuroscience candidate.
It is required for NSCI majors, so yes if you are doing the BS.
Yes, you probably have to do it for neuroscience thesis, but I think it's overall a good set-up for the 2 semester thesis, not too much work but helpful towards the end goal
make sure you have a good advisor and that you meet frequently with them
Yes, required for neuro majors
If you have a good mentor than the research can be great but it totally depends on who is available to teach and work with you. Not much direction is given from the neuroscience major.
Yes! It is both required and fulfilling.
